examples.en: I don't like vain people, regardless of their gender.
examples.ja: 虚栄心の強い人は、男でも女でも苦手です。

examples.en: My parents are the embodiments of vanity.
examples.ja: ウチの親は虚栄心のカタマリです。

examples.en: At that time, I was always on edge, afraid that the people around me would notice my vanity.
examples.ja: 当時は、周りの人たちに自分の虚栄心に気づかれるんじゃないかと、いつもビクビクしていました。

meaning_mnemonic: When how much you <kanji>prosper</kanji> goes into your <kanji>heart</kanji> and just enters a <kanji>void</kanji>, it will rarely mean anything to you. A person who has this trait is going to have extreme <vocabulary>vanity</vocabulary> because he/she just needs to suck more and more prosperity into their bottomless pit of a heart. It's like a black hole. They need more and more and more so then they have to become vain.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That concert was held for the purpose of praying for the recovery from the Great East Japan Earthquake.
examples.ja: そのコンサートは、東日本大震災の復興祈念のためのものでした。

examples.en: In Okinawa, I visited the Peace Memorial Park and the Himeyuri Peace Memorial Museum.
examples.ja: 沖縄では、平和祈念公園と、ひめゆり平和祈念資料館に行きました。

examples.en: We, the employees, would like to offer our prayers for a prosperous and happy new year for all of you.
examples.ja: 皆さまにとって、新年が幸多い年となりますよう、社員一同ご祈念申し上げます。

examples.en: Let's pray for more and more growth and prosperity for Tofugu, cheers!
examples.ja: トーフグの益々の発展と繁栄を祈念して、乾杯！

examples.en: I'll attend the peace memorial service for atomic-bomb victims tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日は原爆犠牲者慰霊平和祈念式典に出席します。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>pray</kanji> with your <kanji>thought</kanji>s, making this a <vocabulary>prayer</vocabulary>.

While 祈願 is about formally asking a specific deity for something, 祈念 refers to <vocabulary>praying</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wishing</vocabulary> in a more silent and personal sense. It's used in formal situations to express hopes for success, safety, peace, or recovery, and often appears in names of monuments or events that combine remembrance and hope, such as 平和祈念公園 (Peace Memorial Park) or 復興祈念イベント (Reconstruction Prayer Event).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm still baffled by trivial things at my age.
examples.ja: 俺は、この年になっても、まだくだらないことに惑うよ。

examples.en: It's curious, isn't it? I wonder what could be making people feel so lost.
examples.ja: 不思議ですね。何が人を惑わせるんでしょうね。

examples.en: People were crying out and fleeing frantically.
examples.ja: 人々は泣き叫び、逃げ惑っていた。

examples.en: That angel has deliberately led you astray.
examples.ja: その天使は、お前が惑うようにわざと仕向けたのだよ。

examples.en: Right now, I just feel at a loss in life.
examples.ja: 今は、なんというか、人生に惑うような気分です。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>misguided</kanji>, but the verb version is usually used to describe how you feel after being misguided — <vocabulary>to be at a loss</vocabulary>!

惑う usually refers to being in a quandary or a state of confusion. Using 惑う is kind of old-fashioned, but other forms like 惑わせる and 逃げ惑う (to flee frantically) are still fairly common in modern Japanese.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you are going <vocabulary>to be at a loss</vocabulary> you're going to be <reading>mad</reading> (まど) about it, most likely. Nobody likes to feel at a loss, so imagine how mad you feel when you are.

examples.en: What’s the name of the dark red flower?
examples.ja: その紅色の花の名前は何ですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same, so this also means <vocabulary>deep red</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>crimson</vocabulary>. Additionally, it can also mean <vocabulary>rouge</vocabulary>, usually in reference to the cosmetic.

紅 is also a bit of an old-fashioned and somewhat literary word, so keep that in mind!
reading_mnemonic:
This is where things get a little complicated. You already learned べに as a reading with 口紅. 紅 can also be read べに just by itself, and in that case, it means <vocabulary>rouge</vocabulary>. However, there’s a different reading that’s used for <vocabulary>deep red</vocabulary>, which we’d like to focus on here, so here’s a mnemonic to help you remember it:

There's so much <vocabulary>deep red</vocabulary> blood everywhere, there's no way of helping this person bleeding out. One might say, <reading>cure ない</reading> (くれない).  Just remember: when there's deep red everywhere, cure ない.

examples.en: It is hard to choose which perfume to wear. It takes me at least an hour every morning.
examples.ja: どの香りを付けるかを決めるのは難しいですね。毎朝短くとも一時間はそれに時間を費やします。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of 香, making it have the same meaning, <vocabulary>fragrance</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The <vocabulary>fragrance</vocabulary> you smell is somebody's <reading>顔</reading> (かお). Just imagine smelling the fragrance of a bunch of people's faces. Yum!

examples.en: "Get two" is a Japanese word derived from English meaning double play.
examples.ja: 「ゲッツー」というのは、併殺を意味する和製英語です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>join</kanji> <kanji>kill</kanji> is when in one play you get two kills (outs) in baseball, making it a <vocabulary>double play</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The more I play, the more I like shogi.
examples.ja: 指せば指すほど将棋が好きになります。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Commander</kanji> <kanji>chess piece</kanji> is a game known as <vocabulary>shogi</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>Japanese chess</vocabulary>, but <vocabulary>shogi</vocabulary> is better). It's similar to chess in a lot of ways and it's pretty interesting. Check it out if you already like chess.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own — just watch out for き turning into ぎ due to rendaku here.

examples.en: The news that his father chose his younger brother as his heir was a huge blow.
examples.ja: 父親が跡継ぎに弟を選んだという知らせは、彼にとって大きな打撃でした。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>traces</kanji> are the people that <kanji>inherit</kanji> what you have. They are your <vocabulary>heir</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>heiress</vocabulary>es. Your <vocabulary>successor</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the vocab words 跡 and 継ぐ put together.

examples.en: That jumping bunny is SO cute.
examples.ja: あのピョコピョコ飛び跳ねている兎が超可愛くてやばい。

meaning_mnemonic: Not to be confused with 跳ぶ, this word has the same meaning. The reading is different, however.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this one is は because you're laughing (<reading>HAHAHA!</reading>!) at the person who put <reading>Nair</reading> (ねる) on their legs, then only finding it to be really painful, so they have <vocabulary>to jump</vocabulary> around to get the pain to go away.

examples.en: I’m skipping rope and listening to FM802.
examples.ja: FM802を聞きながら縄跳びをしています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>rope</kanji> that you <kanji>hop</kanji> over is a <vocabulary>jump rope</vocabulary>. 縄跳び can also refer to the activity of <vocabulary>jumping rope</vocabulary> (aka skipping rope).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the vocab words 縄 and 跳ぶ, put together.

examples.en: He applied for a job as a lifeguard at the community pool only to see girls in bikinis.
examples.ja: あいつ、ビキニ姿のギャルが見れるからっていう理由だけで、市民プールの監視員の仕事に応募したんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: If 応募 is "application" then the verb version is <vocabulary>to apply for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to enlist</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 応募's reading, though knowing the readings of the kanji will take care of things too.

examples.en: I’m excited about seeing his 200th home run today.
examples.ja: 今日は彼の二百本目の本塁打を見るのが楽しみでしょうがないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>hit</kanji> you get in <kanji>baseball</kanji> that takes you to the <kanji>origin</kanji> plate is a <vocabulary>home run</vocabulary>. HOOOMMEERUNNNN!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Oh no! My make-up is coming off again.
examples.ja: ああっ！またお化粧が崩れてきちゃった。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>crumble</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to crumble</vocabulary>, like, something is crumbling or collapsing.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 崩す, so if you know that you know this reading as well!

examples.en: Excuse me, I'd like to refund the balance of my Suica card because I no longer need it...
examples.ja: すみません、もう不要になったのでSuicaの残高を払い戻したいのですが...。

examples.en: Can I get reimbursed for the Korean barbecue I ate during my business trip?
examples.ja: 出張中に食べた焼肉代も払い戻すことはできますか。

examples.en: I’m afraid that we cannot refund your deposit since you lost the key.
examples.ja: 恐れ入りますが、お客様は鍵を失くされたので、保証金の払い戻しは出来かねます。

meaning_mnemonic: 払い is a "payment" and 戻す is "to return." If you return a payment, you are going <vocabulary>to repay</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to refund</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to reimburse</vocabulary> someone for their payment.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 払い and 戻す.

examples.en: Mika said that she feels relaxed when she plays the ukulele.
examples.ja: 美香ちゃんは、ウクレレを弾くと心が休まると言っていたよ。

examples.en: When I tried to play an old guitar, one of the strings broke.
examples.ja: 古いギターを弾こうとしたら、げんが切れてしまった。

examples.en: I was thrilled by the news that he started playing piano again.
examples.ja: 彼がまたピアノを弾き始めたというニュースに、私は胸を躍らせました。

meaning_mnemonic: You'd think that this means "to bullet" but it does not. It means <vocabulary>to play a stringed instrument</vocabulary>. It's actually used for all stringed instruments, and all instruments with a keyboard, like pianos and electric keyboards. Just imagine taking a bullet and using it as a pick for a guitar, then using it to press down the keys of a piano and play a tune.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 引く, which is "to pull." When you play a stringed instrument, you are pulling the string in a direction to make it vibrate and create a sound. So, "to pull" and "to play a stringed instrument" share a reading. It's a bit more of a stretch for instruments with keyboards, but pianos do at least have strings...

examples.en: That person is very polite in their choice of words.
examples.ja: あの人は言葉遣いがとてもていねいです。

examples.en: When I was younger, my seniors often warned me about my language.
examples.ja: 若手時代は、先輩からよく言葉遣いを注意されました。

examples.en: Imitating someone's manner of speech can be a good way to practice a foreign language.
examples.ja: 誰かの言葉遣いを真似することは、外国語の良い勉強法です。

meaning_mnemonic: You may remember 言葉 means "word" and 遣う means "to use." That makes this your <vocabulary>choice of words</vocabulary> or, more simply, your <vocabulary>word use</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 言葉 and 遣う combined together.

examples.en: How much spending money do you give your kid a month?
examples.ja: お子さんには月々お小遣いはいくら渡しているんですか。

meaning_mnemonic: 遣う means "to use," so a "<kanji>small</kanji> use" refers to what you can do with your <vocabulary>spending money</vocabulary>. You're not rolling in dough over here, so you can only use your spending money on small things. Think of it like a little <vocabulary>allowance</vocabulary> you can use to buy baseball cards and bubblegum and stuff.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the alternate reading of 小 and 遣う's reading. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: Could you delete the message I just sent you? I meant to send it to someone else.
examples.ja: 今お送りしたメッセージを削除して頂いてもよろしいでしょうか。別の方に送信するはずだったものなんです。

meaning_mnemonic: If 削除 is "deletion," then the verb version would be <vocabulary>to delete</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This bulletin board belongs to the school.
examples.ja: この掲示板は学校のものです。

meaning_mnemonic: A 掲示 is a notice or sign. Put this on a <kanji>board</kanji>, and it becomes a <vocabulary>bulletin board</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The day is almost over. We couldn’t do anything today because of this stupid traffic jam.
examples.ja: もうすぐ日も暮れるぜ。全くこの馬鹿げた渋滞のせいで今日は一日何にもできなかったな。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>bitter</kanji> <kanji>stagnate</kanji> is when you're stagnated in traffic. It feels bitter, doesn't it? Why can't people drive faster? Why are people looking at the accident instead of driving? I'm so bitter about it! That's why this word is <vocabulary>traffic jam</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>traffic congestion</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: He is a computer geek, but a good looking guy and he’s looking for a girlfriend right now. Aren’t you interested in meeting up with him?
examples.ja: そいつ、パソコンオタクではあるけど、見た目はイケメンで、今彼女募集中なんだ。どう、会ってみない？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Recruit</kanji> and <kanji>gather</kanji> everyone to the <kanji>middle</kanji>. They're all here gathering for this recruitment because we're <vocabulary>now hiring</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>now recruiting</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I didn’t know which way was the way back.
examples.ja: 戻り道がどれだか分からなかったんです。

meaning_mnemonic: If 戻る is "to <kanji>return</kanji>" then you return on the <kanji>street</kanji> you came from, you are taking the <vocabulary>way back</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of everything. Think 戻る for the 戻り portion.

examples.en: You can solve this type of problem by restoring the computer to factory settings, but you can’t regain the lost data if you don’t have a back-up.
examples.ja: コンピュータを出荷時の設定に初期化することでこの問題は解決しますが、バックアップがなければ失われたデータを取り戻すことはできません。

meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>take</kanji> and <kanji>return</kanji> something to yourself is <vocabulary>to take back</vocabulary> something. Give it back!
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 取る and 戻す. Combine them to get this.

examples.en: My house has fire insurance, but what if someone drops an atomic bomb and my house catches on fire? Would I still get the insurance money?
examples.ja: 私の家は火災保険に入っていますが、もし誰かが原子爆弾を落として、それで家が燃えちゃった場合はどうなるんでしょうか。それでも保険金は降りるんでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: 原子 is atom and 爆弾 is bomb. What is an atom bomb? An <vocabulary>atomic bomb</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When I saw a bear’s footprints in the snow, I tightly grasped the knife in my pocket.
examples.ja: 雪の上に熊の足跡を見つけた瞬間、ポケットの中のナイフを握りしめました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Foot</kanji> <kanji>traces</kanji> are <vocabulary>footprint</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of the kanji, put together.

examples.en: Just a word of advice, it looks like he’s aiming to take over your position.
examples.ja: 一応忠告しておくと、奴はお前のポジションを狙ってるみたいだぞ。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember 狙い and how it means "aim"? Make that into a verb, and you have <vocabulary>to aim at</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 狙い, so if you know that you'll be able <vocabulary>to aim at</vocabulary> knowing this word's reading as well.

examples.en: Have you already taken the Japanese version of the Lord of the Ring back to the library?
examples.ja: ロード・オブ・ザ・リングの邦訳、もう図書館に返却しちゃった？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>home country</kanji> <kanji>translation</kanji> is a translation to your home country's language. Since this is a Japanese word, this translation would be a <vocabulary>translation into Japanese</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: How many Japanese residents are there in the United States?
examples.ja: アメリカには在留邦人はどのくらいいるんですか。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>home country</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fellow countryman</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>compatriot</vocabulary> (only for Japanese people though). In Japan, you're a <vocabulary>Japanese national</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Wait a second. By any chance, do I have to pay both federal and state taxes?
examples.ja: ちょっと待って。もしかして、連邦税と州税どっちも払わなきゃいけないの？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Take along</kanji> your <kanji>home country</kanji> to all the other spaces you want to add to your group. Put them together to form the <vocabulary>commonwealth</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>federation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The doorbell rang while he was in the middle of pooping and he rushed to the door without wiping his butt.
examples.ja: 大便の最中に呼び鈴が鳴り、男はお尻も拭かずに玄関へ急いだ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>buzzer</kanji> that will <kanji>call</kanji> you to the door is a <vocabulary>doorbell</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 呼ぶ and 鈴's reading, put together.

examples.en: She put a small bell on the cat's collar.
examples.ja: 彼女は猫の首に小さな鈴をつけました。

examples.en: I attached a bear bell to my backpack and entered the mountain.
examples.ja: クマよけの鈴をリュックにつけて山に入った。

examples.en: I took advantage of my retirement by starting to make small bells.
examples.ja: 退職をきっかけに、鈴作りを始めました。

examples.en: Even though no one was there, in the middle of the night I heard the mournful sound of a bell — tinkle… tinkle…
examples.ja: 誰もいないのに夜中に悲しげな鈴の音が聞こえてきたんです。チリン…チリン…って。

meaning_mnemonic:
The meaning for this word comes from the kanji. It's a <vocabulary>small bell</vocabulary>!

鈴 typically refers to small, spherical bells that jingle or tinkle — think sleigh bells or the bell on a dog collar, or the bells hanging in Japanese shrines that visitors ring before praying (though these can range in size).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Someone is ringing a <vocabulary>small bell</vocabulary>, over and over. It's Ichiro <reading>Suzu</reading>ki (すず) being obnoxious, ringing that <vocabulary>small bell</vocabulary>. I think he's trying to get practice started.

examples.en: I’m going to visit my parents in Gifu at the end of the week.
examples.ja: 週の後半に岐阜の両親のとこに顔を見せに行くつもりだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>branch off</kanji> <kanji>mound</kanji> is the area of Japan known as <vocabulary>Gifu</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Which state is the most prosperous in the U.S.?
examples.ja: アメリカで最も隆盛を極めている州は何州ですか。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Prosperity</kanji> in <kanji>piles</kanji> is a lot of <vocabulary>prosperity</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The adam’s apple is also known as the throat Buddha because the bone shape looks like Buddha.
examples.ja: 喉頭隆起は、その近くにある骨の形が仏様に似ていることから、喉仏としても知られています。

meaning_mnemonic: When <kanji>prosperity</kanji> <kanji>wakes up</kanji> it will push through whatever it's in and create a <vocabulary>protuberance</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bulge</vocabulary>. Just imagine it pushing out of the wall, trying to get out, making a bulge. So prosperous!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Here's a mnemonic for the reading of 起. To get out of this bulge, you use a <reading>key</reading> (き). The key lets you get out.

examples.en: I’d like to hire you, but we can’t wait for your work permit to be issued.
examples.ja: あなたを雇いたいのは山々ですが、就業許可証が発給されるのを待ってはいられないのです。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>employ</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to employ</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You are going <vocabulary>to employ</vocabulary> more people to your business so you can make more money and eventually buy a <reading>yacht</reading> (やと). That's the dream life, it is.

examples.en: Shark has been stepping out of line every chance he gets and I think it’s time for us to let him go.
examples.ja: シャークは事あるごとに規則違反をするので、そろそろ解雇する必要があると思います。

meaning_mnemonic: You are going to <kanji>untie</kanji> the person who is in your <kanji>employ</kanji> from being employed with you. They are free. This means you fired them, which is why this verb means <vocabulary>to fire someone</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Many companies used to guarantee their workers a job for life, but that’s no longer a common thing.
examples.ja: かつては多くの会社が終身雇用を保障していましたが、今ではそれが当たり前では無くなっています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>employ</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji> is <vocabulary>employment</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m drinking a smoothie and painting my walls.
examples.ja: スムージーを飲みながら壁をペンキで塗ってるところです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji!

examples.en: I always use Aya’s illustrations as my desktop wallpapers.
examples.ja: いつも壁紙はアヤのイラストにしています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>wall</kanji>'s <kanji>paper</kanji> is <vocabulary>wallpaper</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. It's what you learned with 壁 and the vocab reading of 紙, rendaku'd.

examples.en: The shogi player has his own practice room in this building.
examples.ja: その棋士は、この建物に自分専用の練習部屋を構えています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>chess piece</kanji> <kanji>samurai</kanji> is someone who plays chess or go, making this word a <vocabulary>shogi player</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>go player</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I come to this Go club every Monday and practice Go.
examples.ja: 毎週月曜日にこの棋院に来て、囲碁を練習しています。

examples.en: I took a souvenir picture in front of the historic Go institution.
examples.ja: 歴史ある棋院の前で記念写真を撮りました。

examples.en: My mother always pulls up in front of the Go hall and drops me off.
examples.ja: 母はいつも棋院の真ん前に車を止めて、私を降ろしてくれます。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>chess piece</kanji> <kanji>institution</kanji> is where you go to play chess... or, in Japan, it's not chess, it's a <vocabulary>Go hall</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>Go club</vocabulary> (it's a very interesting game you should look it up!).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Koichi frowned at the DDoS attack and banged his fist on the table.
examples.ja: コウイチはDDoS攻撃に渋い顔をして、拳で机をバンバンと叩いた。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. The adjective form of <kanji>bitter</kanji> is <vocabulary>bitter</vocabulary>, or more specifically, a <vocabulary>bitter flavor</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: She gives you some food, and it's terribly <vocabulary>bitter</vocabulary>. You look at the lady who gave you this bitter food. You say, "<reading>She boooo</reading>" as in, she's no good, and she serves bitter food.

examples.en: I have poor vision in just one of my eyes.
examples.ja: 片目だけ視力が悪いんです。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>one-sided</kanji> has only one side and not the whole. That's just <vocabulary>one of a pair</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>fragment</vocabulary> of the whole. Stick this onto another word and you have one of a pair or an "incomplete_____."
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: He easily lifted up the heavy bag of rice with one hand.
examples.ja: 彼は重いお米の袋を片手でヒョイと持ち上げました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>one sided</kanji> <kanji>hand</kanji> is one of your hands, that means you're doing something <vocabulary>one handed</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: These readings are the ones you learned with both of these kanji.

examples.en: I managed to get my passport reissued with my broken Japanese.
examples.ja: 私は片言の日本語でなんとかパスポートの再発行をしてもらいました。

examples.en: Our daughter is still little, so she can only speak baby talk.
examples.ja: うちの娘はまだ小さいので、片言ぐらいしかしゃべることができません。

examples.en: Sayaka focused on what Koichi was saying so as to not miss even a few words.
examples.ja: 片言も聞き漏らさないようにサヤカはコウイチの話に集中した。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>One sided</kanji> <kanji>say</kanji>ing things means you don't know both sides of the language, causing you to speak in <vocabulary>broken language</vocabulary>, for example speaking <vocabulary>a few words</vocabulary> in <vocabulary>broken Japanese</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>broken English</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the reading you learned for 片 and the こと of 言葉.

examples.en: I know Hiragana, but I’m still trying to memorize Katakana.
examples.ja: 平仮名は分かりますが、片仮名はまだ覚えきれていません。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>One-sided</kanji> <kanji>kana</kanji> is <vocabulary>katakana</vocabulary>. Might be easier to do the reading first on this one.
reading_mnemonic: 片 is かた, and 仮名 is かな. Put them together to get <vocabulary>katakana</vocabulary>.

examples.en: Can I get two one-way tickets from Osaka to Tokyo?
examples.ja: 大阪から東京までの片道切符を二枚もらえますか。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>one sided</kanji> <kanji>street</kanji> is for <vocabulary>one way</vocabulary> only, because everything just goes in one direction.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. You learned the reading from 片 already, and 道 is the vocab reading みち.

examples.en: When I traveled to Europe during the spring, I saw a flock of white sheep for the first time in my life.
examples.ja: 春にヨーロッパ旅行をした時に、生まれて初めて真っ白な羊の群れを見ました。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji, making it <vocabulary>flock</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: A <vocabulary>flock</vocabulary>? A flock of <reading>cows</reading> (む)! Imagine a flock of cows, probably flying like birds, because flocks usually have something to do with birds.

examples.en: Let me know when you come back from your parents’ house in Gunma Prefecture.
examples.ja: 群馬県の実家から帰ってきたら、知らせてくれよな。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>flock</kanji> of <kanji>horse</kanji>s <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is the part of Japan known as <vocabulary>Gunma Prefecture</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The readings for 群 and 県 are okay, but you haven't learned this reading for 馬 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Gunma Prefecture</vocabulary> is where your <reading>ma</reading>ma (ま) lives! Imagine going back to your mama's house, and finding it's now in Gunma Prefecture. It's a bit of a surprise, but very handy for practicing your Japanese. Thanks mama!

examples.en: The crowd broke out in laughter when the little boy started imitating Justin Bieber.
examples.ja: 小さな男の子がジャスティン・ビーバーの物真似をし出したので、群集は大笑いをしました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>flock</kanji> that has <kanji>gather</kanji>ed is a <vocabulary>crowd</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>multitude</vocabulary>. Because, well, lots of things gathering.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: "I’m just above you," said the hermit on the cloud.
examples.ja: 「わしゃ、お前の真上におるぞ。」と、仙人が雲の上から言いました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>hermit</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>hermit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mountain man</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There were some daffodils in bloom just behind the grave.
examples.ja: お墓の真後ろに、水仙の花々が咲いていました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>hermit</kanji>, for some reason, is a <vocabulary>daffodil</vocabulary>. Just imagine a water hermit dancing around picking <vocabulary>daffodil</vocabulary>s, because he loves 'em! Yayyy daffodils!!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I'll buy a map by the time I go to Sendai.
examples.ja: 仙台に行くまでに地図を買っておきます。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>hermit</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji> is a giant machine that lives in the <vocabulary>Sendai</vocabulary> area of Japan.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We provide good after-sales service because we want to build long-term relationships with our customers.
examples.ja: お客様と末永い関係が築けるよう、充実したアフターサービスをご提供しております。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Allocate</kanji> the <kanji>truth</kanji> more and more to make things better. The truth is, we need to allocate even more, until we've reached <vocabulary>fullness</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You can charge your phone in my car, if you’d like.
examples.ja: もしよければ俺の車で携帯の充電ができるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Allocate</kanji> <kanji>electricity</kanji> back to the battery with a <vocabulary>recharge</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Could you refill the printer paper before you leave?
examples.ja: 帰る前にプリンタの紙を補充しておいてもらえるかな。

meaning_mnemonic:
To take a <kanji>supplement</kanji> and <kanji>allocate</kanji> it to where it needs to be is to <vocabulary>resupply</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>refill</vocabulary> something.

補充 means filling in the gaps when there's a shortage. It's used for things like <vocabulary>restock</vocabulary>ing supplies, replacing what's been used, or adding more staff to meet demand. The goal is to bring things back to a needed or complete level.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We managed to avoid the worst possible outcome of bankruptcy.
examples.ja: 倒産という最悪の結末だけは何とか免れることができた。

examples.en: I'll do anything to escape execution.
examples.ja: 死刑執行を免れるためなら何でもします。

examples.en: We avoided serious injury because we sat in the back seat and wore our seat belts.
examples.ja: 後部座席に座ってシートベルトを締めていたので、私達は重傷を免れました。

meaning_mnemonic: You are going to <kanji>excuse</kanji> yourself from the situation, and in order to do that, you have <vocabulary>to escape from</vocabulary> the person / thing trying to hold you there in order <vocabulary>to avoid</vocabulary> them.
reading_mnemonic: In order to do that, you jump inside your <reading>man(u) car</reading> (まぬか) which is a car for a tough man(u) that needs to drive fast, just like you.

examples.en: I’ll give you the diploma the next time we meet.
examples.ja: 今度お会いする際に免状をお渡ししますね。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>excuse</kanji> for the current <kanji>condition</kanji> is surprising, especially considering your <vocabulary>diploma</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>license</vocabulary> on the issue.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: "Ah. I forgot how much I love driving. I have got to get my license renewed." "Wait! Has your driver’s license expired? Omg. That’s it! Pull over right now!"
examples.ja: 「あぁ、自分がどれだけドライブが好きか忘れてたわ。免許更新しなくちゃ。」「おい、待てよ！お前の免許失効してるのか？ありえねえ。よし、それまで！今すぐ横につけて！」

meaning_mnemonic: You have an <kanji>excuse</kanji> that <kanji>permit</kanji>s you to do what you want. It is a <vocabulary>license</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>certificate</vocabulary> allowing you to do this.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Do you know where the duty-free shops are?
examples.ja: 免税店がどこにあるかご存知ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>excuse</kanji> from <kanji>tax</kanji>es? That's a <vocabulary>tax exemption</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Sorry. I won’t be able to pick you up at the airport today. You should’ve asked me earlier.
examples.ja: 御免。流石に今日の今日で、空港まで迎えに行くのは無理だわ。もうちょっと早く言ってくれたらよかったのに。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>honorable</kanji> <kanji>excuse</kanji> is all I have, and that is no good. I'm <vocabulary>sorry</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>I beg your pardon</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My grandfather was exempt from military service because he had a heart disease.
examples.ja: 私の祖父は心臓病を患っていたため、兵役を免除されました。

meaning_mnemonic:
To <kanji>excuse</kanji> and to <kanji>exclude</kanji>, that's <vocabulary>exemption</vocabulary>.

免除 means granting relief or exemption from a duty or obligation that would otherwise be required, like paying tuition fees, repaying debts, obtaining specific licenses for certain activities, and so on.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: After I got resignation advice from the personnel department and I still didn’t quit my job, I was transferred to a useless position.
examples.ja: 人事部に辞職勧告を受けた後もなお仕事を続けていたら、窓際族に追いやられてしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: If you take what you <kanji>recommend</kanji> and <kanji>announce</kanji> it to the world, you are making a <vocabulary>recommendation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Oh no. My brother said that he’d call me on my cell, but there’s no reception here.
examples.ja: しまった！兄ちゃんが俺の携帯に電話するって言ってたのに、ここ圏外だわ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>range</kanji> is <kanji>outside</kanji> of the range, meaning you're <vocabulary>out of range</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’ve never thought that Singapore was an English-speaking country.
examples.ja: シンガポールが英語圏だとは思ってもみなかったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>English</kanji> <kanji>range</kanji> is the areas where people speak English, aka the <vocabulary>English Speaking World</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Are there any animals other than penguins in the Antarctic Circle?
examples.ja: 南極圏にはペンギン以外にも動物はいるんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 南極 means "South Pole" or the "Antarctic"? Add <kanji>range</kanji> onto that word and you get the region known as the <vocabulary>Antarctic Circle</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings all three kanji. You've seen the vocab word 南極 before as well, so you should be OK with this one!

examples.en: What brings you to Saitama prefecture?
examples.ja: どうして埼玉県に来たんですか。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>cape</kanji> <kanji>ball</kanji> <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is <vocabulary>Saitama Prefecture</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of 埼 and 玉, and the regular reading for 県.

examples.en: Her mother told her that their puppy's life was stolen by an evil spirit.
examples.ja: 母親は、少女に、悪霊が犬の命を奪ったのだと教えました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rob</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to rob</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I’m watching a movie while I eat my meal.
examples.ja: 映画を見ながら御飯を食べています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>honorable</kanji> <kanji>meal</kanji> is <vocabulary>cooked rice</vocabulary>. It's the meal of Japan.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Have you been to the third floor and seen the new rooms already?
examples.ja: もう三階へ行かれて新しい部屋を御覧になられましたか？

meaning_mnemonic:
Add an <kanji>honorable</kanji> little 御 for someone to <kanji>look at</kanji> when you want to show respect to them. 御覧になる is the honorific form of 見る, so it still means <vocabulary>to look</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to see</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to watch</vocabulary>, but with a more respectful tone.

You'll often use it when someone of higher status than you is doing the looking and you want to sound like a polite, refined adult who's showing proper respect to them. Keep in mind that the first 御 is often written in kana, like ご覧になる.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: People on the train should refrain from having cell phone conversations.
examples.ja: 電車の乗客は、携帯での会話を慎むべきだ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you have <kanji>humility</kanji> you will try <vocabulary>to be discreet</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Why are you going <vocabulary>to be discreet</vocabulary>? Because that <reading>tutu she</reading> (つつし) wears is really embarrassing.

examples.en: What makes you so careful?
examples.ja: どうしてそんなに慎重なんですか。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Humility</kanji> is <kanji>heavy</kanji>, so it's best nobody knows your secret. You should be <vocabulary>discreet</vocabulary> instead.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just need to remember the alternative reading for 重. If you aren't discreet or careful, the evil Mrs. <reading>Chou</reading> (ちょう)will find you and kill you!

examples.en: My family doctor refused to let me get the colorectal cancer screening done.
examples.ja: 私のかかりつけのお医者さんは、私が大腸癌検査を受けるのを拒みました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>refuse</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to refuse</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: What are you refusing? You are refusing a child, because children are all bad. You say "<reading>子 ba</reading>d, <reading>子 ba</reading>d" over and over again.

examples.en: He was called coward since he’d refused to go to the battlefield.
examples.ja: 彼は戦場に行く事を拒否したため、臆病者と呼ばれた。

meaning_mnemonic: I <kanji>refuse</kanji>. I am saying "<kanji>no</kanji>." That is my <vocabulary>refusal</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I want to exchange the window frames from wood to stainless steel.
examples.ja: 窓枠を木からステンレスのものに取り替えたい。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: We just made the framework for future reforms in Tofugu’s Japanese learning materials.
examples.ja: トーフグの日本語学習教材改革のための枠組みが出来上がりました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>frame</kanji> <kanji>group</kanji> is a <vocabulary>frame</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>framework</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the reading of 枠 and the reading of the vocab word 組み. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: I got a tattoo on my left instep.
examples.ja: 左足の甲にタトゥーを入れました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

甲 has traditionally meant <vocabulary>turtle shell</vocabulary>, but these days it appears much more often in expressions like 足の甲 (<vocabulary>instep</vocabulary>) and 手の甲 (<vocabulary>back of the hand</vocabulary>). If you think about it, those body parts kind of resemble turtle shells, don’t you think?
reading_mnemonic: This word is made up of a single kanji, but it uses the on'yomi reading, not the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you've learned this reading already. Yay!

examples.en: Thanks to his efforts, the newsletter was able to avoid being discontinued.
examples.ja: 努力の甲斐があって、そのニュースレターは廃刊になるのを免れた。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>turtle shell</kanji> that is <kanji>patterned</kanji> has much more <vocabulary>worth</vocabulary> than a boring non-patterned turtle shell. It probably has a better <vocabulary>effect</vocabulary> too if you throw it at your opponent in a go-kart race or something — give it a shot and see what the <vocabulary>result</vocabulary> is!

甲斐 doesn't mean "worth" in the sense of monetary value, but rather in the sense that some action you took paid off or was worth doing. You'll usually see it paired with verbs or other nouns, like 苦労の甲斐があった (it was worth the trouble) or 頑張った甲斐があった (trying hard paid off).
reading_mnemonic:
You haven't learned this reading for 甲 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

It's <vocabulary>worth</vocabulary> it to chuck turtle shells out of your <reading>ca</reading>r (か) and try to hit other cars. Sure, it's a little dangerous, but the <vocabulary>effect</vocabulary> is that the other cars get slowed down or knocked over, which has the <vocabulary>result</vocabulary> of your car overtaking them. Totally worth it.

examples.en: What do you think is the problem with the Japanese social welfare system?
examples.ja: 日本の社会福祉制度の問題点とは何だと思いますか。

meaning_mnemonic: You have much <kanji>luck</kanji> in your <kanji>welfare</kanji>, making you have good <vocabulary>welfare</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>well being</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Tofugu is suspending publication of its blog because all Tofugu members are busy harvesting rice.
examples.ja: トーフグメンバーはみんな稲刈りで忙しいので、トーフグのブログは休刊中です。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the いね reading of this kanji. You can think of it like you're saying "いいね!" at the rice plant you're looking at (just shorten the い).

examples.en: My friend has much bigger rice fields.
examples.ja: 友達はもっと大きい稲田をもっていますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>rice plant</kanji> <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> is a <vocabulary>rice field</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rice paddy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses kun'yomi readings for 稲 (いな) and 田 with rendaku (だ). You may not be familiar with the いな reading yet, but it appears in a lot of compounds that use 稲, so it's good to know. Here's a mnemonic to help:

There's a popular road trip game in Japan where every time you pass a rice field, you have to <reading>ea</reading>t <reading>na</reading>chos (いな). See a rice field? Eat nachos. And if you've ever driven through rural Japan, you know how many rice fields (and eaten nachos) that adds up to. I once gained five pounds in two hours on a drive through Niigata… It wasn't pretty. But the rice fields were.

examples.en: He is immersing himself in rice cultivation.
examples.ja: 彼は稲作に没頭しています。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>make</kanji> a <kanji>rice plant</kanji> then you are doing <vocabulary>rice cultivation</vocabulary>, since you're making it from the seed to the harvest and doing it all!
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses a kun'yomi reading for 稲 (いな) and the usual on'yomi reading for 作. You may not be familiar with the いな reading yet, but it appears in a lot of compounds that use 稲, so it's good to know. Here's a mnemonic to help:

When you do <vocabulary>rice cultivation</vocabulary>, you should <reading>ea</reading>t <reading>na</reading>chos (いな). You need all the calories and carbs from some loaded-up nachos to get ready for the hard work of rice cultivation, you know? Mmm, you'd happily do rice cultivation every day if it meant you could eat nachos.

examples.en: He gave me an old novel that is out of print.
examples.ja: 彼は、絶版になっている古い小説を私に譲ってくれました。

meaning_mnemonic: If you are going to <kanji>defer</kanji> to someone, you are going <vocabulary>to concede</vocabulary> something. I concede / defer this to you.
reading_mnemonic: What are you conceding? Some delicious <reading>yuzu</reading> (ゆず). You are sad, because they're so much better than lemons and now you don't have them.

examples.en: The principal doesn’t want to transfer his authority to someone else.
examples.ja: 校長が権力を他の人に移譲したがらないんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Shift</kanji> something and <kanji>defer</kanji> it somewhere else. This is a <vocabulary>transfer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>assignment</vocabulary>.

This is a formal term used to describe the legal transfer of rights, properties, or liabilities, so it's most commonly seen in official or legal documents.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: What made you assume that it was humble Japanese?
examples.ja: どうしてそれが謙譲語だと思ったんですか。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Language</kanji> when you <kanji>defer</kanji> to <kanji>modesty</kanji> is <vocabulary>humble Japanese</vocabulary>. Of course, this doesn't have to refer to Japanese, though it usually does, meaning this could mean <vocabulary>humble language</vocabulary> as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I can’t believe that humble man was actually a member of the mafia.
examples.ja: その謙虚な男性が実はマフィアの一員だったなんて、信じられません。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>modesty</kanji> <kanji>void</kanji> is that big pit you go into when you are showing <vocabulary>modesty</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>humility</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When I found the classic car that had been discontinued in 1960 that I’d been looking for, I was so happy my heart leapt.
examples.ja: ずっと探していた60年代に生産中止になったクラッシックカーを見つけた時は、嬉しくて胸が躍りました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>leap</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to leap</vocabulary>. It also means <vocabulary>to jump</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to bounce</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You go <vocabulary>to leap</vocabulary> and leap again. You do it so much that you start sweating, which is causing a foul <reading>odo</reading>r (おど) to come from your body.

examples.en: In this industry, the active participation of women really stands out.
examples.ja: この業界では、女性の活躍が目立ちます。

examples.en: Amazing! You did a great job!
examples.ja: すごい！大活躍でしたね！

examples.en: This player is expected to perform well in the future.
examples.ja: この選手は、今後の活躍が期待されています。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>lively</kanji> <kanji>leap</kanji> is what you do when you have <vocabulary>active participation</vocabulary> in an <vocabulary>activity</vocabulary> and often find <vocabulary>success</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>do great</vocabulary>.

This word is usually used to describe someone's outstanding or remarkable activity in a certain sport, career, or other field or activity. Have a look at the common word combinations for some example usages.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This lesson is aimed at improving students’ leaping, jumping, and hopping skills.
examples.ja: この授業は、生徒たちの跳躍力を伸ばすことを目的としています。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>hop</kanji> and <kanji>leap</kanji> into the air, you probably are doing a <vocabulary>jump</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>leap</vocabulary> into the air.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Does this gun have bullets in it?
examples.ja: この銃、弾入ってる？

examples.en: Can I buy this firearm with a credit card?
examples.ja: こちらの銃は、クレジットカードで買えますか。

examples.en: My mother found my gun in my room while I was out.
examples.ja: 外出中に、部屋に置いてあった銃が母親に見つかってしまったんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: There was a tragic incident where a dog was shot and killed by its owner.
examples.ja: 犬が飼い主に銃殺されるという悲しい事件がありました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>gun</kanji> <kanji>kill</kanji> is a <vocabulary>death by shooting</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Could you hang on a second? I have to get my bullets.
examples.ja: 少し待って貰ってもいいですか？ちょっと銃弾を取りに行かなくてはならないので。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>gun</kanji>'s <kanji>bullet</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bullet</vocabulary>, though this word can specifically refer to a <vocabulary>rifle bullet</vocabulary> as well (probably because it was mostly rifles that people had way back in the day).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: After a long time we eventually succeeded in finding the pistol that was used for the crime.
examples.ja: しばらく時間はかかったが、ようやく犯行の凶器となった短銃を見つけることができました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>short</kanji> <kanji>gun</kanji> is a <vocabulary>pistol</vocabulary>, because it's not long like a rifle, it's a short gun!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: "Okay! Let’s move on to the next item on the agenda." "Wait! Why don’t we take a ten-minute break before moving on instead?"
examples.ja: 「それでは、アジェンダの次の項目へ進みましょう。」「ちょっと待って下さい。次へ進む前に、10分間の休憩を取りませんか？」

meaning_mnemonic: You need to go through a <kanji>paragraph</kanji> in chunks that you can easily see with your <kanji>eye</kanji> so you break it up by <vocabulary>item</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you out with 目. If you can't see this <vocabulary>item</vocabulary> in the paragraph with your eye, someone will <reading>mock</reading> (もく) you for sure.

examples.en: Please fill out the necessary items on the form and mail it to us.
examples.ja: 用紙に必要事項を記載のうえ、郵送をお願い致します。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know 事 means "occurrence," but it can also mean "matter." So a <kanji>matter</kanji> <kanji>paragraph</kanji> shows the <vocabulary>matter</vocabulary>s, <vocabulary>item</vocabulary>s, or <vocabulary>subject</vocabulary>s that make up a larger issue or discussion at hand.

事項 is a formal word usually seen at the end of another phrase that specifies what matters or items are being referred to, like 注意事項 (matters to be noted) or 協議事項 (items for discussion).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: For more details, please see the applicant guidelines attached.
examples.ja: 詳細については、添付の募集要項をご確認くださいませ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>need</kanji>ed <kanji>paragraph</kanji> contains the <vocabulary>important points</vocabulary> of what you want to say.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: How much is the steel armor in the game?
examples.ja: そのゲームで鋼の鎧っていくらだったっけ？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You take a look at the <vocabulary>steel</vocabulary>. It's shaped like a person. Turns out you turned that hag into a steel statue. You say, "huh, that's the <reading>hag ね</reading>?" (はがね). Whoops, sorry hag lady.

examples.en: We have to deal with the steel shortage as soon as possible.
examples.ja: 鋼材不足には早急に対処する必要があります。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Steel</kanji> <kanji>material</kanji> is <vocabulary>steel material</vocabulary>. Boom!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If you cut their wages, the steelworkers might go on strike.
examples.ja: 賃金カットなんかしたら、製鋼所の工員達がストライキを起こすかもしれませんよ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>manufacture</kanji> <kanji>steel</kanji> that is <vocabulary>steel manufacture</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The contents are way too extreme to be published.
examples.ja: このコンテンツは、過激すぎて掲載することはできません。

meaning_mnemonic: 掲載 is <kanji>publication</kanji> so the verb version of that is <vocabulary>to publish</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to print</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will also help to know 掲載 as well.

examples.en: Why do prisoners wear striped clothes?
examples.ja: どうして囚人はしましまの服を着ているんですか。

examples.en: The prisoners' tools were stored away there.
examples.ja: そこには、囚人達の道具がしまわれていた。

examples.en: A record was found that showed the prisoner had joined the army in 1998.
examples.ja: その囚人が、1998年に軍隊に入隊していた記録が見つかった。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>criminal</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> will end up as a <vocabulary>prisoner</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>inmate</vocabulary> if they get caught!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Condemned criminals climb these stairs and make their way to the gallows.
examples.ja: 死刑囚はこの階段を登って死刑台へと向かうんだ。

examples.en: It was that death row convict who caused the problem in the first place.
examples.ja: そもそも、この問題を起こしたのは、あの死刑囚だ。

examples.en: That lawyer presented nothing but information that was favorable to the death row inmate.
examples.ja: その弁護士は、死刑囚にとって有利な情報ばかりを並べた。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 死刑 means "death penalty?" Well a <kanji>criminal</kanji> who has been sentenced to it is a <vocabulary>condemned criminal</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>death row convict</vocabulary>. They're condemned to death.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Who’s the reserve player?
examples.ja: 控えの選手には誰がいたっけ？

meaning_mnemonic:
Something that can <kanji>abstain</kanji> until it's needed makes for good <vocabulary>backup</vocabulary>. Think about it — you don't want backup rushing in too early, right? It should abstain until the backup is actually needed.

Note that 控え isn't used for spares and extras. It's more for necessary backups, like a backup player in sports, a document <vocabulary>copy</vocabulary> for record keeping, or a <vocabulary>receipt stub</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You learned this reading already! Good for you!

examples.en: I still have no news about my father.
examples.ja: 依然父の消息は不明です。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you have a <kanji>dependent</kanji> <kanji>nature</kanji>, then even if you go off on your own, you're <vocabulary>still</vocabulary> going to ask for help. Dependent people still need help because that's just how they are.

Note that you need to add と to the end of this word to make it an adverb, and たる to make it an adjective!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Even though I just shaved my eyebrows three hours ago, I'm already starting to get a unibrow.
examples.ja: 三時間前に眉毛をそったばかりなのに、もう眉毛がつながりそうだ。

examples.en: I dyed my eyebrows to match my dress.
examples.ja: ドレスの色に合わせて、眉毛を染めたの。

examples.en: It takes me a couple hours to draw my eyebrows on every morning.
examples.ja: 眉毛を書くのに毎朝二時間くらいかかる。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>eyebrow's</kanji> <kanji>hair</kanji> is the individual <vocabulary>eyebrow</vocabulary> hair that makes them up.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this! Just watch out for the rendaku that changes the 毛 reading to げ.

examples.en: It looks like there is an error in this address.
examples.ja: この宛名は間違っているみたいです。

examples.en: I was entrusted with the task of writing names and addresses.
examples.ja: 宛名書きの仕事を任された。

examples.en: I lost the list of customer names and addresses.
examples.ja: 顧客の宛名リストを紛失してしまった。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>address</kanji> <kanji>name</kanji> is the name that's on the address, making it the <vocabulary>addressee</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>name and address</vocabulary>.

This can be used for both physical mail and email.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 宛 is the same one you learned for the kanji. The reading for 名 comes from the kun'yomi reading, which you learned in the vocabulary word 名 and 名前. So, the reading for this word is <reading>あてな</reading>.

examples.en: He is from a family of honorable lineage.
examples.ja: 彼は由緒正しい家系の出身です。

examples.en: This place was originally a venerable shrine.
examples.ja: ここは元々は由緒正しい神社なんですよ。

examples.en: I have fallen in love with a woman of honorable lineage.
examples.ja: 由緒正しい生まれの女性に恋をしてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: Someone or something whose 由緒 (lineage) is 正しい (correct) is <vocabulary>of honorable lineage</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>venerable</vocabulary> indeed.
reading_mnemonic: You already know the readings for 由緒 and 正しい so you just need to put them together to read this word.

examples.en: The rainy season lasts from June to July in Japan.
examples.ja: 日本の六月から七月は梅雨のシーズンです。

examples.en: The rainy season started in Kanto yesterday.
examples.ja: 関東は昨日梅雨に入ったそうです。

examples.en: I don't like the rainy season because it gets too humid, but I also don't like how it suddenly gets really hot once it ends.
examples.ja: 梅雨はジメジメして嫌だけど、梅雨が明けて一気に暑くなるのも嫌なんだよなぁ。

meaning_mnemonic:
In the <kanji>ume</kanji> season, it <kanji>rain</kanji>s a lot in Japan (and some other East Asian countries). That's why <kanji>ume</kanji> <kanji>rain</kanji> means <vocabulary>rainy season</vocabulary>. It usually happens from the end of May to mid-July, when ume get ready to be harvested. 

Keep in mind this is a seasonal word unique to Japan and East Asia, so you usually don't use it to refer to rainy seasons that happen in other regions of the world.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses an exceptional reading, so don't try to read this with the kanji readings you already learned. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Rainy season</vocabulary> is a special season <reading>to you</reading> (つゆ). All of your favorite things in the year happen during rainy season, like… staying inside all day because all it does is rain! But to you, there's nothing better than rainy season.
